title: 103_hr3489
content: The Act may be cited as the "Infrastructure Reinvestment and Economic Revitalization Act of 1993". Congress finds that the quality of the nation's transportation infrastructure is crucial for economic productivity and competitiveness. To compete globally, the US must increase infrastructure investment, as other countries have tripled their productivity growth rates through capital investment. Neglecting infrastructure investment has led to a significant drop in the US's gross national product percentage allocated to infrastructure. The Act aims to issue bonds for immediate infrastructure reinvestment, create new jobs, stimulate economic growth, and improve efficiency in infrastructure maintenance. This is in response to the neglect of infrastructure investment, leading to decay, traffic congestion, and higher costs. Creating a new financing mechanism to provide immediate funds, complementing the goals of the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991. The Infrastructure Reinvestment Fund will receive 2.5 cents per gallon of taxes from the Highway Trust Fund, as determined by the Secretary. This fund is created to provide immediate funds in line with the goals of the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991. The Infrastructure Reinvestment Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by 2.5 cents per gallon of certain taxes. The Fund is available for carrying out specific purposes outlined in the Infrastructure Reinvestment and Economic Revitalization Act of 1993. The Infrastructure Reinvestment Fund, established in the Treasury of the United States, is funded by taxes for specific purposes outlined in the Reinvestment and Economic Revitalization Act of 1993. Authorized repayable advances to the Fund must be fully amortized before October 1, 2024, based on a 30-year bond schedule using infrastructure reinvestment taxes. Repayment of advances and interest is required. The Infrastructure Reinvestment Fund will be repaid with interest as per the Secretary's terms. No advances will be made after September 30, 2024, and all advances must be repaid by that date. Interest rates will be determined according to section 9509(d)(3)(C). SEC. 4. OFF-BUDGET STATUS OF FUND. The Infrastructure Reinvestment Fund's receipts and disbursements are not included in budget calculations. SEC. 5. INFRASTRUCTURE REINVESTMENT PROGRAM. Authorization of Appropriations from the Infrastructure Reinvestment Fund for fiscal year 1995 to the Secretary for surface transportation programs. Funds shall remain available until expended. Allocation of funds among programs based on a formula. Apportionment formulas and other provisions apply. The 1993 Act states that funds for surface transportation programs are subject to various requirements, such as apportionment, Federal share, and planning. Funds under subsection (a) are not subject to obligation limitations. Approval of grants or contracts with these funds creates a contractual obligation for the Federal share of the cost. The 1993 Act outlines requirements for surface transportation program funds, including apportionment, Federal share, and planning. Funds under subsection (a) are not subject to obligation limitations and approval of grants or contracts creates a contractual obligation for the Federal share of the cost. The 1993 Act defines the Secretary as the Secretary of Transportation and the surface transportation program as programs or projects funded under the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991. It excludes certain projects and the national recreation trails funding program. The 1993 Act excludes the national recreation trails funding program under part B of title I of the Act.
